Commutative Law
A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Left Coset
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A left coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $aH = \{ah; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
Coefficient of a Polynomial

Given a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], the i-th coefficient a_i is called the coefficient of degree i.
Intersection of Ideals
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Ring Automorphism
An automorphism of a ring $R$ is an isomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
A-homomorphism
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
Subfield
A subring $T$ of a field $K$ is called a subfield if $T$ is a field itself.
Algebraically closed field

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.
Splitting field of Family of Polynomials

A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).
Orbit
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
Disjoint Cycles
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Subset
A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of a left coset (concept 1) depends on the concept of a subset (concept 11) because a left coset is defined as a subset of a group.

The definition of the intersection of ideals (concept 3) depends on the concept of a subset (concept 11) because the intersection is defined as the set of elements that are in both ideals, which is a subset of the ring.

The definition of a ring automorphism (concept 4) depends on the concept of a subfield (concept 6) because an automorphism is an isomorphism from a ring to itself, and subfields are specific types of subrings that are fields.
The definition of a subfield (concept 6) depends on the concept of a subset (concept 11) because a subfield is a subset of a field that is itself a field.
The definition of an algebraically closed field (concept 7) depends on the concept of the coefficient of a polynomial (concept 2) because it involves polynomials and their coefficients.

The definition of a splitting field of a family of polynomials (concept 8) depends on the concept of an algebraically closed field (concept 7) because a splitting field is defined in terms of the decomposition of polynomials into linear factors, which is a property of algebraically closed fields.
The definition of an orbit (concept 9) depends on the concept of a subset (concept 11) because an orbit is defined as a subset of the set on which the group acts.
The definition of disjoint cycles (concept 10) depends on the concept of a subset (concept 11) because disjoint cycles are defined in terms of sets that have no elements in common.
